title: User & Client Interviews
overview: User and client interviews help you collect real insights about what people do, need, and value. Talking to both clients (who set goals and constraints) and users (who actually interact with the system) reveals not only functional requirements but also social and ecological impacts.
purpose: User and client interviews help you uncover functional needs, goals, and success criteria while also surfacing social impacts (fairness, accessibility, well-being) and ecological impacts (resource use, environmental footprint). They highlight differences between client priorities and user realities, building empathy and evidence for ethical, responsible design decisions.

steps.title: Prepare Open Questions
steps.description: Write 3–5 open-ended questions. Mix functional, social, and ecological aspects.

steps.title: Identify Interviewee Type
steps.description: Adapt your questions depending on whether you’re interviewing a client (strategic goals, risks) or a user (daily tasks, pains, accessibility).

steps.title: Run the Interview
steps.description: Interview one person at a time. Let them speak freely, avoid yes/no questions, and listen actively.

steps.title: Capture Responses & Behaviors
steps.description: Note down answers, examples, and non-verbal cues like hesitations or emphasis.

steps.title: Summarize Findings
steps.description: Bring the team together to review the notes and summarize key insights, needs, and sustainability considerations.

input: A clear understanding of project context.
Notebook or template for capturing responses.
prompts: I am preparing for an interview about [insert project description]. Suggest 5–7 open-ended questions I can ask to explore functional needs, social aspects (inclusion, fairness, well-being), and ecological aspects (resource use, environmental footprint). Make them clear and easy to understand.
I am interviewing a [client/user] about [insert project description]. Suggest polite follow-up questions I can ask when the interviewee gives short or vague answers, so I can get richer insights.
Here are my raw interview notes: [paste notes]. Summarize the key insights into three categories: functional needs, social impacts, and ecological impacts. Highlight overlaps, gaps, or surprises.
Based on these summarized interview findings: [paste summary], suggest what areas my team should explore further to better address sustainability in our design.
tips: Start with 'Tell me about…' instead of yes/no questions.
Listen more, talk less — aim for 80% interviewee talking.
Ask follow-ups like 'Can you give an example?' to go deeper.
Afterward, check: did we capture both people and planet impacts?
For clients: focus on long-term goals, risks, and sustainability requirements.
For users: explore everyday routines, frustrations, and accessibility needs.

title: Stakeholder Impact Map
overview: This tool helps you see who and what is affected by your product. It connects human, non-human, and systemic actors across different impact levels to make sure your design considers people, communities, and ecosystems.
purpose: Identify human and non-human stakeholders, map their impacts at individual, social, and environmental levels, and uncover who might be excluded or vulnerable — helping you design with broader ethical and sustainability awareness.

steps.title: Place Your System
steps.description: Write your product, service, or concept in the center of the map.

steps.title: Add Human Actors
steps.description: Include users, clients, workers, and communities directly involved or affected.

steps.title: Add Non-human Actors
steps.description: List technologies, infrastructures, natural systems, data, rules, or species that are involved or impacted.

steps.title: Map Impacts Across Levels
steps.description: Consider effects on: Individual (micro), Social (meso), and Environmental/Systemic (macro).

steps.title: Review & Reflect
steps.description: Check who might be missing (marginalized groups, invisible workers, future generations) and refine the map.

input: Basic understanding of your product or problem space.
Knowledge about potential users, stakeholders, and context.
Template or whiteboard for mapping actors and impacts.
prompts: I am mapping stakeholders for [insert project description]. Suggest human actors (users, workers, communities) and non-human actors (technology, ecosystems, infrastructures, rules) that could be relevant.
For this list of stakeholders [paste list], identify which might be excluded, marginalized, or less visible — including future generations or ecosystems.
For my system [insert system name], summarize likely impacts at three levels: Individual (micro), Social (meso), and Environmental/Systemic (macro).
Based on these mapped impacts [paste notes], suggest questions my team should ask to ensure we are not overlooking vulnerable groups or environmental risks.
tips: Be specific — instead of writing 'society,' name the actual group or community.
Push beyond obvious users to include invisible or non-human actors.
Always check impacts at all three levels (micro, meso, macro).
Revisit and update the map as your project evolves.
Use the Conscious Digital Product Principles as a guide for reflection.

title: Inclusive User Groups
overview: This tool helps you design for real, diverse user groups. It highlights needs, pains, privileges, roles, and gains — so you avoid stereotypes and include marginalized voices.
purpose: Make user groups visible without oversimplifying, check privilege and exclusion risks, and build user stories that balance needs and gains.

steps.title: Fill in User Group Data
steps.description: Add facts about the group’s age, gender, abilities, background, or financial safety. Use real data sources, not assumptions.

steps.title: Check Privilege
steps.description: Use the Wheel of Power to critically reflect on the group’s advantages and disadvantages (e.g., access to resources, influence, technical expertise).

steps.title: Define the Group’s Role
steps.description: Describe the group’s role in relation to your product (e.g., daily user, tester, decision-maker).

steps.title: Capture Needs & Pains
steps.description: List what this group struggles with (e.g., access barriers, lack of time, ease-of-use problems).

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Identify benefits this group gets from your product.

steps.title: Write a User Story
steps.description: Summarize the group’s perspective: 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains].'

input: User research data (demographics, behaviors, accessibility needs).
prompts: I am designing for a user group: [describe group]. Suggest key data points I should collect about this group (age, abilities, background, safety, etc.) without stereotyping.
For this user group [describe group], list potential struggles and barriers they may face when using [product/service].
Based on this description [insert group], analyze what privileges this group might have and what disadvantages they might face (access, influence, technical expertise).
Create a user story in the format: 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains]' for this group: [paste group info].
tips: Be specific, not generic (e.g., 'international student on a budget' instead of just 'students').
Avoid assumptions — base everything on data sources where possible.
Ask: Who is missing? Always consider marginalized groups and accessibility needs.
Combine with Systemic Journey Maps to see how different user groups interact over time.

title: Systemic Journey Map
overview: This tool helps you map the user’s journey step by step while reflecting on functional, social, and ecological impacts. It connects what users do with who is affected and how design choices ripple across society and the environment.
purpose: Break down user experiences into clear phases, link design choices to social and environmental impacts, and uncover not only what happens but also who is affected and in what way.

steps.title: Define a User Story or Scenario
steps.description: Start with a user story: 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains].' This anchors the journey map.

steps.title: Set Journey Phases
steps.description: Break the experience into clear stages or steps.

steps.title: Capture User Actions
steps.description: For each phase, write down what the user actually does.

steps.title: Add User Goals
steps.description: Describe what the user wants to achieve at each phase.

steps.title: Identify Pain Points & Needs
steps.description: Note problems, struggles, or resources the user needs.

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Highlight benefits or positive outcomes for the user at each phase.

steps.title: Map Environmental Impacts
steps.description: Record how each phase affects the environment (e.g., energy use, waste, travel, resources).

steps.title: Map Social Impacts
steps.description: Record how each phase affects people or communities (e.g., inclusion, fairness, equity, collaboration).

steps.title: Consider Orders of Impact
steps.description: Look at first, second, and third-order impacts to see long-term and systemic effects.

steps.title: Add Data & Insights
steps.description: Include any supporting data, research findings, or extra notes at the bottom.

input: A clear user story or scenario.
Knowledge or idea of the product or service flow.
Awareness of possible social and environmental factors.
prompts: I am mapping a user journey for [project description]. Suggest 5 possible phases of the journey and key user actions for each phase.
For this journey [paste phases + actions], list potential user goals, pain points, and gains at each phase.
For this user journey [paste details], identify possible social impacts (inclusion, fairness, collaboration) and environmental impacts (energy, waste, resource use) at each phase.
Based on this journey map [paste details], describe first-order, second-order, and third-order impacts that might emerge over time.
tips: Don’t just describe actions — ask why each step matters long term.
Start with simple examples to get going, then refine.
Push beyond individual impacts — consider community and environment.
Keep it visual and concise: icons or quick notes work better than long text.
Use the Conscious Digital Product Principles as a guide to check your thinking.

title: Conscious Requirements
overview: This tool helps you connect user stories to concrete interactions. It shows how different actors (people or systems) achieve goals, highlights dependencies, and surfaces sustainability risks early.
purpose: Turn user needs into clear scenarios, map interactions between actors, and reveal risks, barriers, or sustainability issues before they become design flaws.

steps.title: Start with a User Story
steps.description: Write a user story in the format: 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains].'

steps.title: Add Actors
steps.description: Identify the people, systems, or tools involved in the interaction.

steps.title: Create Use Cases
steps.description: For each actor, define what they do to achieve the goal.

steps.title: Show Flows & Dependencies
steps.description: Connect use cases with arrows to show sequence, dependencies, or handovers between actors.

input: A clear user story or scenario.
Awareness of relevant human and non-human actors (e.g., users, systems, tools, environment).
Template for mapping actors and use cases.
prompts: This is my user story for [user story description]. Suggest 3–5 possible use cases
For this user story [paste story], list potential actors (people, systems, or tools) and what each does to reach the goal.
Based on these actors and use cases [paste list], suggest dependencies, handovers, or flows that might exist between them.
For this set of use cases [paste details], identify potential hidden impacts, such as resource needs, risks, or ecological trade-offs.
tips: Keep use cases short and action-focused (e.g., 'User uploads file,' not 'The system maybe allows…').
Always include non-human actors when relevant (e.g., tech, data, infrastructure, environment).
If multiple paths exist to achieve a goal, map them all.
Use this tool early to detect risks and sustainability gaps in your requirements.

title: Prototyping Playground
overview: This tool helps you quickly test ideas, layouts, and interactions. It’s about experimenting fast, not creating polished designs. Use it to explore inclusivity and sustainability in early design.
purpose: Turn abstract concepts into something tangible, test different layouts and flows, and surface inclusivity or sustainability issues early without investing too much time.

steps.title: Use Elements & Placeholders
steps.description: Start with basic elements (buttons, inputs, text, placeholders) to build small parts.

steps.title: Build Screens
steps.description: Connect elements into simple screens that show the user flow.

steps.title: Test with Others
steps.description: Share prototypes to check: Is it clear? Is it accessible?

steps.title: Adjust Quickly
steps.description: Iterate fast — this stage is for learning and improving, not polishing designs.

input: Basic elements like text, buttons, and placeholders.
prompts: I want to prototype [describe feature/idea]. Suggest 3–5 simple layouts I could try to test different user flows.
Here’s my prototype description [paste details]. Suggest quick accessibility checks (color, font size, clarity) I should run.
For this prototype [paste description], suggest ways to make it more inclusive (different abilities, contexts) and more sustainable (reduce waste, simplify interactions).
tips: Keep prototypes low-fi first — sketchy, simple shapes are enough.
Check accessibility: color contrast, font size, readability.
Avoid waste by keeping interactions simple — don’t overcomplicate.
Ask: Would this design work for people with different abilities or contexts?
